title: Council Regulation (EEC) No 105/85 of 14 January 1985 opening, allocating and providing for the administration of a Community tariff quota for frozen beef and veal falling within subheading 02.01 A II b) of the Common Customs Tariff (1985)
header:
COUNCIL  REGULATION (EEC) No 105/85
of 14 January 1985
opening, allocating and providing for the administration of a Community tariff quota for frozen beef and veal falling within subheading 02.01 A II b) of the Common Customs Tariff (1985)
THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN
COMMUNITIES
main_body:
1. A Community tariff quota for frozen beef and veal falling within subheading 02.01 A II b) of the Common Customs Tariff, totalling 50 000 tonnes expressed as boned or boneless meat, is hereby opened for 1985.
For the purpose of charging imports against this quota, 100 kilograms of unboned meat shall be taken to be equivalent to 77 kilograms of boned or boneless meat.
2. Imports of those goods which have been admitted under the benefit of another preferential tariff regime shall not be set off against this tariff quota.
3. The Common Customs Tariff duty for this quota shall be 20 %.

1. An initial instalment of 49 500 tonnes shall be allocated among Member States, their shares being defined below.
This amount shall be divided into two parts, one totalling 33 165 tonnes and the other 16 335 tonnes, broken down as follows:
1.2.3 //   //   //   //   // For the part totalling 33 165 tonnes  // For the part totalling 16 335 tonnes  //   //   //  // Benelux  // 3 157  // 1 555  // Denmark  // 155  // 77  // Germany  // 5 960  // 2 935  // Greece  // 1 693  // 832  // France  // 3 310  // 1 631  // Ireland  // 3  // 2  // Italy  // 9 561  // 4 709  // United Kingdom  // 9 326  // 4 594  //   //   //
2. The second instalment, covering an amount of 500 tonnes, shall constitute the reserve. Allocation of the amounts in the reserve shall take place according to the procedure provided for in Article 27 of Regulation (EEC) No 805/68.

1. The Member States shall take all appropriate steps to guarantee all persons concerned, established within their territories, free access to the quota shares allocated to them.
2. The extent to which the shares of the Member States have been used up shall be verified on the basis of imports as the product is presented for customs clearance under the declaration for free circulation.
The Member States shall regularly inform the Commission of imports which have been charged against their shares.
The Member States and the Commission shall cooperate closely to ensure that this Regulation is complied with.

The Commission shall, not later than 1 October 1985, submit to the Council a report on the quantities for which licences have been delivered in each Member State.
The Council, acting by a qualified majority on a proposal from the Commission, shall, where appropriate, re-allocate the amounts which have not been used up.

This Regulation shall enter into force on the day of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Communities.
This Regulation shall be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States.
